docs.title: 🌞 SUNCAST — Software UNified Collaboration for Advancing Solar Tomography
docs.text:
Welcome to SUNCAST, an open-science initiative dedicated to developing a modern, sustainable, and community-driven software ecosystem for advancing 3D studies of the solar corona.

SUNCAST supports research that combines ground-based and space-based remote-sensing observations with physics-based forward modeling, spectral fitting, and data-constrained tomography. The SUNCAST ecosystem is built around interoperable, cloud-ready tools and reproducible workflows that help the community analyze, model, and understand the 3D structure of the solar corona.

docs.title: 🎯 Mission
docs.text:
SUNCAST accelerates scientific discovery by:

  • providing open, interoperable, HPC-ready software tools,
  • supporting the transition from legacy codes to scalable, cloud-capable systems,
  • training early-career researchers and broadening participation (MSIs, PUIs, and beyond),
  • fostering reproducibility and open-science best practices,
  • building a community-owned, community-driven software ecosystem.

Our development practices are guided by the FAIR, CARE, and TRUST principles, ensuring transparency, reproducibility, ethical stewardship, and long-term sustainability.

docs.title: 🧭 Governance & Community
docs.text:
SUNCAST is establishing a Governance Board and community processes that support:

  • transparent decision-making,
  • open participation,
  • long-term sustainability of key workflows,
  • recognition of contributor effort,
  • equitable access to tools and training resources.

You can learn more about how SUNCAST is governed and how to get involved in the Governance and Contributing pages.

docs.title: 🔭 Core Tools & Workflows
docs.text:
SUNCAST currently supports and develops several key tools, including:

  • pyGSFIT — microwave spectral fitting and forward modeling of solar emission,
  • pyAMPP — NLFFF-based magnetic modeling and data-constrained field reconstruction,
  • pyGSK — Generalized Spectral Kurtosis (GSK) toolkit for radio data analysis.

Additional community workflows, real-data pipelines, and training examples will be added as the project grows. See the Projects page for an evolving overview.

docs.title: 🤝 Join the SUNCAST Community
docs.text:
SUNCAST welcomes contributions from:

  • students and early-career researchers,
  • scientists at MSIs and PUIs,
  • international collaborators,
  • anyone interested in open, reproducible heliophysics.

Start by reading our Contributing Guide and Code of Conduct, then explore the projects and repositories hosted under the SUNCAST GitHub organization.

Together, we can build a sustainable, community-owned software ecosystem for solar tomography and heliophysics.

docs.title: 🌍 SUNCAST Code of Conduct
docs.text:
SUNCAST is committed to fostering an open, welcoming, inclusive, and respectful environment for all contributors, users, and collaborators.

This Code of Conduct applies to all SUNCAST spaces, including:

  • GitHub repositories and discussions,
  • issue trackers and Pull Request threads,
  • workshops, meetings, and training events,
  • community communication channels.

docs.title: 🤝 Our Pledge
docs.text:
We pledge to make participation in SUNCAST a harassment-free experience for everyone, regardless of:

  • age
  • body size
  • disability
  • ethnicity
  • gender identity and expression
  • level of experience
  • nationality
  • personal appearance
  • race
  • religion
  • sexual identity and orientation

We commit to creating a positive and inclusive environment that encourages respectful collaboration and scientific advancement.

docs.title: Examples of positive behavior
docs.text:
• Using welcoming and inclusive language
  • Being respectful of different viewpoints and experiences
  • Giving and gracefully accepting constructive feedback
  • Accepting responsibility and apologizing when mistakes are made
  • Focusing on the collective benefit of the community

docs.title: Examples of unacceptable behavior
docs.text:
• Harassment or discrimination of any kind
  • Offensive verbal comments or imagery
  • Personal attacks or insults
  • Publishing private information without explicit permission
  • Sustained disruption of discussions or meetings
  • Intentionally harmful or deceptive actions

docs.title: 🧭 Enforcement Responsibilities
docs.text:
• The SUNCAST Governance Board (once established), or
  • the provisional PI-led governance team

will oversee enforcement of this Code of Conduct.

Project maintainers and community organizers are encouraged to report issues or seek guidance from the governing team.

docs.title: 🚩 Reporting Misconduct
docs.text:
If you witness or experience a violation of this Code of Conduct, please report it confidentially to:

suncast-admin@njit.edu (or the official contact address designated by the Governance Board)

Reports will be handled with discretion and care. Retaliation for reporting is not tolerated.

docs.title: 🛠 Enforcement Guidelines
docs.text:
Possible responses to violations include:

  1. Warning — for minor or accidental violations.
  2. Temporary Ban — for repeated or more serious violations.
  3. Permanent Ban — for harassment, threats, or sustained harmful behavior.

The exact response will depend on the severity and context of the situation.

docs.title: 🌟 Acknowledgments
docs.text:
This Code of Conduct is adapted from the Contributor Covenant v2.1, used widely across open-source communities.

By participating in SUNCAST, you agree to abide by this Code of Conduct and help maintain a respectful, constructive, and collaborative environment.

docs.title: 🌟 Contributing to SUNCAST
docs.text: Thank you for your interest in contributing! SUNCAST welcomes contributions from researchers, students, and developers worldwide. This page provides the practical steps required to contribute code, documentation, or new tools.

docs.title: 🧰 Contribution Workflow (For All Repositories)
docs.text:
1. Fork the repository you want to contribute to (under the suncast-org organization).
  2. Create a feature branch for your work: bash git checkout -b my-feature
  3. Make your changes (code, docs, tests, examples).
  4. Commit with clear messages: bash git commit -m "Add new SK threshold example"
  5. Push your branch to your fork: bash git push origin my-feature
  6. Open a Pull Request (PR) to the repository under suncast-org.
  7. Participate in the review process and address comments as needed.

After approval, a maintainer will merge your contribution.

docs.title: 🌱 Starting New Projects
docs.text: If you want to propose a new tool or workflow:

docs.title: Option A: Independent development (recommended for new ideas)
docs.text:
1. Create the repository under your personal GitHub account.
  2. Develop and test your idea freely.
  3. When the project is ready for broader use, request a repository transfer into the SUNCAST organization.

This models the bottom-up contribution path and allows for experimentation before committing to long-term maintenance.

docs.title: Option B: Start directly under SUNCAST (for coordinated efforts)
docs.text: If the project is part of a planned SUNCAST deliverable or collaborative effort, ask a maintainer or Governance Board member (once established) to create a repository under suncast-org. From there, everyone contributes via forks and PRs.

docs.title: 🧪 Standards & Expectations
docs.text:
• Code should follow the conventions of the language (Python or IDL).
  • Documentation and examples are strongly encouraged for new features.
  • All code must use an OSI-approved open-source license.
  • Tests are encouraged when appropriate.
  • PRs should be small, focused, and clearly described.

docs.title: 🌍 Community Values
docs.text:
SUNCAST commits to:

  • respectful collaboration,
  • transparent governance,
  • reproducible science,
  • inclusive participation,
  • recognition of contributor effort.

Please also review the Code of Conduct before engaging in community spaces.

Thank you for helping grow the SUNCAST ecosystem!

docs.title: 🛠️ SUNCAST Governance Model
docs.text: SUNCAST is committed to building an open, inclusive, and sustainable ecosystem of tools and workflows for data-driven solar tomography and heliophysics research. To support a diverse contributor community, SUNCAST provides two complementary paths for participating in software development.

docs.title: 🚀 1. Organization-Initiated Projects (Top-Down Path)
docs.text:
SUNCAST may create repositories directly under the suncast-org GitHub organization when:

  • the project is a flagship workflow,
  • it supports core deliverables (e.g., pyGSFIT, pyAMPP, pyGSK),
  • or it is part of an NSF-funded activity.

docs.title: Contribution workflow
docs.text:
1. The repository is hosted under suncast-org.
  2. Contributors fork the repository to their own accounts.
  3. All additions or fixes are proposed via Pull Requests (PRs).
  4. A maintainer reviews, discusses, and merges the PR.

This ensures transparency, reproducibility, and long-term code sustainability.

docs.title: 🌱 2. Contributor-Initiated Projects (Bottom-Up Path)
docs.text:
SUNCAST also supports independent scientific innovation. Any researcher, student, or collaborator may:

  1. Create and develop a new tool in their own personal GitHub repository.
  2. Mature the project independently during its early exploratory phase.
  3. When ready, request that the project be transferred to the SUNCAST organization.

docs.title: After transfer
docs.text:
• Full commit history is preserved (provenance protected).
  • The original author may serve as a maintainer.
  • Additional contributors participate through forks + PRs.

This path enables open participation and encourages early creativity without requiring prior permission from SUNCAST.

docs.title: 📜 3. Guiding Principles
docs.text: All SUNCAST repositories and contributions follow:

docs.title: FAIR Principles
docs.text:
• Findable
  • Accessible
  • Interoperable
  • Reusable

docs.title: CARE Principles
docs.text:
• Collective Benefit
  • Authority to Control
  • Responsibility
  • Ethics

docs.title: TRUST Principles
docs.text:
• Transparency
  • Responsibility
  • User Focus
  • Sustainability
  • Technology

These values guide software design, documentation, licensing, and community engagement.

docs.title: 🧭 4. Governance Structure (In Formation)
docs.text:
SUNCAST is establishing a Governance Board consisting of:

  • core developers,
  • domain scientists,
  • early-career contributors,
  • representatives from participating institutions.

The Board will:

  • maintain development standards,
  • review contribution proposals,
  • approve repository transfers,
  • guide documentation and reproducibility,
  • coordinate training and community support.

Until the Board is formally established, the SUNCAST PI team serves as the interim governing body.

docs.title: 🤝 5. How to Get Involved
docs.text:
You can contribute by:

  • submitting issues or feature requests,
  • improving documentation,
  • contributing examples or tutorials,
  • submitting Pull Requests,
  • developing independent projects and transferring them into SUNCAST,
  • participating in SUNCAST workshops and community forums.

SUNCAST welcomes contributors from all backgrounds and especially encourages participation from MSIs, PUIs, students, and early-career researchers.

docs.title: 👥 Maintainers — Roles & Responsibilities
docs.text: This page describes the responsibilities, expectations, and roles of maintainers in the SUNCAST ecosystem.

docs.title: 🛠️ Maintainer Role
docs.text:
Maintainers are trusted contributors who help steward the long-term health, stability, and quality of SUNCAST repositories.

A maintainer is responsible for:

  • Reviewing and merging Pull Requests
  • Ensuring contributions follow FAIR, CARE, and TRUST principles
  • Maintaining code quality and documentation standards
  • Participating in governance discussions
  • Supporting contributors and answering technical questions
  • Managing releases and versioning (when applicable)

docs.title: 1. Pull Request Review
docs.text:
• Ensure PRs are clear, documented, and consistent with project goals.
  • Request changes when necessary.
  • Approve and merge PRs that meet standards.
  • Encourage contributors by providing constructive feedback.

docs.title: 2. Issue Management
docs.text:
• Triage issues and label them appropriately.
  • Close resolved or inactive issues.
  • Engage with user feedback and help clarify problem reports.

docs.title: 3. Release Management
docs.text:
• Follow semantic versioning (where applicable) for tagged releases.
  • Maintain CHANGELOG entries or release notes.
  • Coordinate with the SUNCAST Governance Board or PI team as needed.

docs.title: 4. Communication
docs.text:
• Maintain respectful, constructive communication in all public and private channels.
  • Encourage new contributors and mentor early-career participants.
  • Represent SUNCAST values in all interactions.

docs.title: 🧭 Maintainer Appointment
docs.text:
Maintainers may be appointed by:

  • the SUNCAST Governance Board (once established), or
  • the provisional PI-led governance team during the initial phase.

Candidates are typically:

  • active contributors,
  • developers of major features or workflows,
  • individuals committed to SUNCAST’s open-science mission.

docs.title: 🔄 Maintainer Offboarding
docs.text:
If a maintainer becomes inactive for 6+ months or chooses to step down:

  • they retain authorship and contribution credit,
  • they may be listed as an “Emeritus Maintainer,”
  • repository permissions will be updated to maintain clarity and stability.

Maintainers are essential for the sustainability of the SUNCAST ecosystem. Your service supports open science, reproducibility, and community-driven innovation.

docs.title: 🛰️ SUNCAST Projects
docs.text: This page provides an evolving overview of key tools and workflows associated with the SUNCAST ecosystem. Many of these live in separate repositories under the SUNCAST GitHub organization.

docs.title: pyGSFIT
docs.text:
• Purpose: Microwave spectral fitting and forward modeling of solar emission.
  • Highlights:
  • Modern Python implementation of legacy spectral fitting workflows.
  • Supports multi-frequency microwave observations.
  • Designed for reproducibility and integration into training environments.

docs.title: pyAMPP
docs.text:
• Purpose: NLFFF-based magnetic modeling and data-constrained field reconstruction.
  • Highlights:
  • Bridges observational data and 3D magnetic models.
  • Targets cloud/HPC-ready workflows.
  • Serves as a foundation for tomography extensions.

docs.title: pyGSK
docs.text:
• Purpose: Generalized Spectral Kurtosis (GSK) toolkit for radio data analysis.
  • Highlights:
  • Implements the Nita & Gary GSK estimator.
  • Supports both simulation and real-data workflows.
  • Forms the basis for RFI detection and quality control pipelines.

docs.title: Community Workflows (Examples)
docs.text:
SUNCAST will host and showcase real-data and training workflows, such as:

  • OVRO–LWA Spectral Kurtosis Pipelines (e.g., SK-based quality control and RFI detection),
  • Tomographic Reconstruction Workflows that combine EUV, radio, and other diagnostics,
  • Educational Notebooks and Training Modules for workshops and summer schools.

As these workflows mature, they will be documented and linked from this page.

docs.title: Contributing New Projects
docs.text:
If you are developing a tool or workflow that aligns with SUNCAST goals, you can:

  1. Develop it independently in your personal GitHub space.
  2. Reach out to the SUNCAST team when it is ready for broader use.
  3. Propose a repository transfer into the SUNCAST organization.

See the Contributing Guide and Governance Model for details on top-down and bottom-up project integration paths.
